If I click the refresh button, and then switch to another VT it cancels the update refresh.

events.target_title: gThumb hangs when some mount point is unavailable

note.body:
Gthumb should not scan all drives; what is the point of this?  It should just focus on the targeted directory.  And if there is a hang against a drive, there should be a dialog box showing up after a 1s delay stating which drive it is waiting for and allow the user to cancel, reverting then to the home directory.

BTW, in my case, the hang is not infinite.  It is just a long timeout.  The image eventually shows up.

events.target_title: Cannot map multiple USB connected touchscreens with identical make and model
tab does not indicate drive is disconnected
Drop target on tab is not big enough
Offer fixing the "invalid filename" when copying to NTFS and file name contains an invalid character
Be a little more helpful with renaming duplicate files
spacebar selects a file in filechooser
Be a little more helpful with renaming duplicate files

note.body:
For example, Mac does this:
![Screen_Shot_2020-01-15_at_5.41.03_PM](/uploads/55dbc2a2f121b8344d3882f7e610dc2d/Screen_Shot_2020-01-15_at_5.41.03_PM.png)

And keep both creates a file called WW-1-2914_Documents copy.pdf

Nautilus has similar capability: if you right click and select "Copy to..." and choose the current directory it creates a filename with " (copy)" appended (I wonder if a "duplicate" menu item might be nice). It seems like following that would work well.

I am on rolling Arch.

mutter 3.34.3
gtk3 1:3.24.13-1
GNOME Shell 3.34.3

Lights Off 3.34.0

Version 3.34.2

events.target_title: Add new blue based style. Thanks to Will Farrington.

note.body: line 34 has a name of neon_pink but the colour is a yellow. 'value="#ffdd00"' should probably have been 'value="#ff00dd"'

events.target_title: Add new blue based style. Thanks to Will Farrington.

note.body:
Jeffery and Christian

I'm happy to leave it to you to decide whether to change the name or the
colour.

For your interest. I've used the cobalt style for years but one annoying
aspect of it was/is html special characters, e.g. /“/, which I
found hard to read (maybe age related :-)). After a bit of investigating
I discovered these are displayed in the XML Style - /xml:entity/ which
was set to /#blue/. I changed it to /neon_pink/ and it showed up as
yellow. I decided the color value was wrong so created my own copy of
cobalt.xml and changed /neon_pink/ to /#ff00dd/ and /xml:entity/ to
/neon_pink.

/Kind regards

Angus
//

events.target_title: Add new blue based style. Thanks to Will Farrington.

note.body: line 34 has a name of neon_pink but the colour is a yellow. 'value="#ffdd00"' should probably have been 'value="#ff00dd"'

events.target_title: Add new blue based style. Thanks to Will Farrington.

note.body:
Jeffery and Christian

I'm happy to leave it to you to decide whether to change the name or the
colour.

For your interest. I've used the cobalt style for years but one annoying
aspect of it was/is html special characters, e.g. /“/, which I
found hard to read (maybe age related :-)). After a bit of investigating
I discovered these are displayed in the XML Style - /xml:entity/ which
was set to /#blue/. I changed it to /neon_pink/ and it showed up as
yellow. I decided the color value was wrong so created my own copy of
cobalt.xml and changed /neon_pink/ to /#ff00dd/ and /xml:entity/ to
/neon_pink.

/Kind regards

Angus
//

Copied text from rich text editors seems to be stored in the clipboard as a bitmap in X11

note.body: Merging !939 may result in a better default if text is available from the clipboard, but it will *not* resolve this issue. A clipboard manager should not suppress available types and offer a subset or request some "best type" and hand that over before a target application decided about the format it wants to paste.

events.target_title: Copied text from rich text editors seems to be stored in the clipboard as a bitmap in X11

note.body: If the clipboard manager is not transparent (i.e. offering all types the source application offers), it should not interfere with the clipboard at all as long as the source application is open and can be asked for the format the destination application wants. In the case of LibreOffice these can be internal formats a clipboard manager never will handle. If the source application exits, the clipboard manager should store and manage all formats the applications wants to store in the clipboard for further use by other applications. These must not be limited to text/plain or image/* offers.

events.target_title: Please add memory (M+, M-, Mr and Mc) functions....
Please add memory (M+, M-, Mr and Mc) functions....

note.body:
Hi Robert,

Thanks so much for the quick reply!

My use of the Memory function(s) is fairly simplistic: perform one calculation (say A / B), M+ the result, perform second calculation (say C x D), then multiply that result by MR.

Or to perform various multiple individual calcs, M+'ing (or M-'ing) the individual results to create a final answer, retrieve with a press of the MR button.

I guess that some of these things may be achieved via other methods (probably involving calc history and various additional mouse-clicks), but having individual buttons for these 4 functions makes number-crunching far simpler.

I've been having a look at other Linux calculator options, but the ones I found still had some drawbacks:

KCalc - probably one of the better ones, but the amount/size of required dependencies is a bit much (Linux Mint xfce 64-bit). It implements the M+/-/R/C functionality, pretty much in the exact way a physical calculator would.

galculator - Implements it in a slightly strange/non-intuitive way, as the 'buttons' don't seem to work as a real calc.

If it were possible to add the 4 buttons/features (M+, M-, MC and MR) in the same way as a physical calc, it would make things much more usable, for me and a few others - I've noticed that the lack of these functions is an issue for a number of others when looking at reviews/comments on other Linux calculator programs.

In regards to the questions you asked:

1: I guess the retention of the memory could be persistent, depending on a flag in preferences? One a physical calculator it typically is erase upon power-off, so this would be fine too.

2: #69 wouldn't really affect things (for me at least), since it's really the presence of the actually buttons (M+/-/R/C) that's required.

I understand that this may require a fair bit of additional programming and that you probably have a sizeable list of other features to implement, but it would be a nice addition to any future release. :-)

Once again, thanks for the reply!

Cheers,

Mike.

Or to perform various multiple individual calcs, M+'ing (or M-'ing) the individual results to create a final answer, retrieve with a press of the MR button.

I guess that some of these things may be achieved via other methods (probably involving calc history and various additional mouse-clicks), but having individual buttons for these 4 functions makes number-crunching far simpler.

I've been having a look at other Linux calculator options, but the ones I found still had some drawbacks:

KCalc - probably one of the better ones, but the amount/size of required dependencies is a bit much (Linux Mint xfce 64-bit). It implements the M+/-/R/C functionality, pretty much in the exact way a physical calculator would.

galculator - Implements it in a slightly strange/non-intuitive way, as the 'buttons' don't seem to work as a real calc.

If it were possible to add the 4 buttons/features (M+, M-, MC and MR) in the same way as a physical calc, it would make things much more usable, for me and a few others - I've noticed that the lack of these functions is an issue for a number of others when looking at reviews/comments on other Linux calculator programs.

In regards to the questions you asked:

1: I guess the retention of the memory could be persistent, depending on a flag in preferences? One a physical calculator it typically is erase upon power-off, so this would be fine too.

2: #69 wouldn't really affect things (for me at least), since it's really the presence of the actually buttons (M+/-/R/C) that's required.

I understand that this may require a fair bit of additional programming and that you probably have a sizeable list of other features to implement, but it would be a nice addition to any future release. :-)

Once again, thanks for the reply!

Cheers,

Mike.

gfileutils: make g_file_set_contents() always fsync()

note.body: For your information. If a stronger guarantee is wanted that the file makes it to the disk, an additional sync should be added. [0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch](/uploads/4c3d5e0f1de846d5ff0876952efb6e5d/0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch)

events.target_title: g_file_set_contents() can fill target with NUL bytes if it did not previously exist

note.body:
For your info. If you want to have a more reliable g_file_set_contents() an additional sync is needed: [0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch](/uploads/3dee7919dc6ac8b487ada615294a2158/0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch)

Something weird seems to happen when uploading patches, since it seems to remove the commit log:
```
While rename does atomically rename, it doesn't provide durability. So
flush the directory so the meta-data is on the disk as well, before
reporting g_file_set_contents was successfull, so even in case of a
crash the new contents will be there.

For our use case: embedded product with ubifs, which doesn't have a
workaround for buggy applications [1] that behavior is wanted. For
e.g. connman stores the Wifi password etc with g_file_set_contents.
When power cycling the device after entering the Wifi settings, the
entered settings should be used directly. Not after an unknown amount
of time.

[1] http://www.linux-mtd.infradead.org/doc/ubifs.html#L_sync_exceptions
```

note.body:
Okay, here's an update.

I'm able to login to the Riot instance from Fractal by changing the provider url from `riot.im/app` to `matrix.org`. (That make sense, since matrix.org is the identity server and riot uses it). Figured it out by playing around. Custom server is still out of the question. Planning to try with a self hosted one.

With that being said, the following are worth doing.
1. Updated documentation
2. Server validation in the "Provider" page.

Closing this issue.

events.target_title: French translation update + ‘New file’ feature
French translation update + ‘New file’ feature
French translation update + ‘New file’ feature
French translation update + ‘New file’ feature

note.body:
When you have a program which takes data from small binary files, you can create such a file using GHex with the ‘New file’ feature and the insert mode. It will likely be for testing purposes or to create a data file for an arbitrary program.

It’s also a handy feature to test GHex and to nurture the idea that binary files can be created and manipulated like a familiar document (as many reverse-engineering works suggest) — :wink:.

Anyway it’s only a few lines of code.

I hope you’re okay with other changes (described in commit messages) too.

events.target_title: French translation update + ‘New file’ feature

note.body:
Is there a guide somewhere that says how to deal with translations in this project? I commonly update all the PO files with new strings when there are new ones or for each release, so that translators can just pick the file, write their translations and submit the result, but it seems it was not managed this way before. Some PO files have not been updated during many years, e.g. help/it/it.po in master is based on a template from 2007.

GHex’s help is actually quite outdated too. I should work on it.

  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python
==> glib
Bash completion has been installed to:
  /usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d
==> icu4c
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:

  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:

note.body:

==> Caveats
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python

icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:

==> Caveats
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python

  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python
==> glib
Bash completion has been installed to:
  /usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d
==> icu4c
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python
==> glib
Bash completion has been installed to:

==> icu4c
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run

You can install Python packages with

They will install into the site-package directory

  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python
==> glib
Bash completion has been installed to:
  /usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d
==> icu4c
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

events.target_title: Sharing of Playlists using Rygel
Sharing of Playlists using Rygel

note.body:
Thanks for your reply. 
      My intent is to create playlists based on different criteria, such as; Beach, Christmas, Folk, etc.  I understand my library is currently exposed as a playlist of its own.  I have thousands of files. Using separate edited playlists to play subsections would be far more convenient in parsing this library from any particular client.  It's the sharing of these edited playlists that I am having issues with. 
I have been looking at rygel.conf and wondering if I can simply do something there to achieve this goal.

Thanks
Frank Mosuch

note.body:
How do I set the event object for dragging a clip from media library?
`       

        timeline_container = common.create_timeline_container()
        timeline = timeline_container.timeline

        clip = GES.TitleClip()
        layer = timeline.ges_timeline.append_layer()
        layer.add_clip(clip) 

        with mock.patch.object(Gtk, "get_event_widget") as get_event_widget:
            get_event_widget.return_value = clip.ui

            event = mock.Mock()
            event.x = 0
            event.get_button.return_value = True, 1
            timeline._button_press_event_cb(None, event)
            self.assertIsNotNone(timeline.dragging_element)

            def translate_coordinates_func(widget, x, y):
                return x, y
            clip.ui.translate_coordinates = translate_coordinates_func
            event = mock.Mock()
            event.get_state.return_value = Gdk.ModifierType.BUTTON1_MASK
            event.x = 1
            event.y = 0
            event.get_button.return_value = True, 1
            timeline._motion_notify_event_cb(None, event)
            self.assertTrue(timeline.got_dragged)

        # Release the mouse button.
        event = mock.Mock()
        event.get_button.return_value = True, 1
        timeline._button_release_event_cb(None, event)`
This is the code I have right now but how do I drag and drop from media library?
I need help on this one.
Thanks

Use fastjar or jar instead of unzip when available (and warn if not for large files)
Use fastjar or jar instead of unzip when available (and warn if not for large files)

note.body:
I was trying to find out if I could make this PR myself but I got stuck looking through the source.

Here in fr-archive-libarchive.c we say that `_g_program_is_available("unzip", check_command)` is `false` then we add read to the capabilities...

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/file-roller/blob/master/src/fr-archive-libarchive.c#L141

But then here we add read to the capabilities if that same expression is `true`: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/file-roller/blob/master/src/fr-command-zip.c#L423

I'm confused. I mean, the second one seems more logical to me, but yeah I don't get it.

note.body: I was able to recreate your change locally from mutter!1004 and it seems to make a noticable difference, so that's good news. I still notice stuttering on the animation when you zoom into a workspace that you've clicked, but the initial overview opening is much smoother!

events.target_title: Display scaling on HiDPI display causes poor animation performance on Intel graphics

note.body: I forgot to add, that this also appears to be related to vsync. If I use a .drirc to disable vsync, the animations don't stutter, albeit with tearing. I wonder if there's some optimizations to be made with the handling of intel vsync and clutter/gnome-shell?

note.body: I was able to recreate your change locally from mutter!1004 and it seems to make a noticable difference, so that's good news. I still notice stuttering on the animation when you zoom into a workspace that you've clicked, but the initial overview opening is much smoother!

events.target_title: Display scaling on HiDPI display causes poor animation performance on Intel graphics

note.body: I forgot to add, that this also appears to be related to vsync. If I use a .drirc to disable vsync, the animations don't stutter, albeit with tearing. I wonder if there's some optimizations to be made with the handling of intel vsync and clutter/gnome-shell?

note.body:
Hello, 

I was having a similar problem, it was because the Network Manager openvpn does not support push-peer-info, to solve the problem I created a patch and submitted to the debian bugs system  https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=948035.

The patch add support for the push-peer-info for the import, gui and the openvpn helper. Currently export will not work.

regards,
Peder.

System-modal dialogs block access to useful stuff - make them window-modal instead

note.body:
Reading the issue description, I have some comments.  I think that the *only* legitimate reason for any interaction with the system to be system-modal is if the user directly triggered the dialog and it does not make any sense for the user to interact with the system in any way other than to respond immediately to the dialog.  So:

>  There are two situations when I think we do want dialogs to be system-modal:
> 1. When the action is about a significant system-wide change. Here, system-modality means that the user doesn't lose the dialog, and it elevates the seriousness and authority of the dialog. A good example of this is the end session dialogs.

I think the end session dialogs are about the only example of this.  If I click "Log Out", then I'm either going to log out (by confirming or ignoring the dialog for 60 seconds) or I'm going to cancel.  Clicking "Log Out" and then doing something else in the 60 second window without first dismissing the dialog is silly.

This justification has nothing to do with seriousness or authority.  If the system is about to run out of power, for example, this is extremely serious, but making me take immediate action to send a dialog away instead of, say, saving my work is a waste of time.  There are plenty of ways for the shell to get my attention or even force my attention without a system-modal dialog.

> 2. When the dialog was triggered from the shell. This is mostly because we don't want free-floating shell dialogs.

I'm not sure what the issue with free-floating dialogs is, but I can think of many ways to handle shell-triggered questions for the user, all of which are better than system-modal dialogs.  Taking as an example a prompt for a network password:

1. If I click a network and a password is needed, the password prompt could be in the network dropdown.  Windows works like this and it's nice.

1. If I click a network and a password is needed or if an automatically connected network needs a password, a free-floating dialog could appear.  This may be less thematically aligned with the shell than a system-modal would be, but that doesn't seem like a big deal.  Sure, this is not very elegant, but I think it is in no respect worse than a system-modal dialog.

1. If an automatically connected network needs a password, a door-hanger style notification could drop down from the same place where the list of networks appears (top-right by default).  I can continue working with the system without responding, but it can't get lost behind other things.  It **must not** steal keyboard focus -- stealing keyboard focus for something that will be transmitted over a network is a security problem.

1. If an automatically connected network needs a password, a system-modal dialog could appear.  This interrupts my workflow, is completely incompatible with password managers, transmits potentially sensitive keystrokes over the network, and causes users to curse at GNOME.  It's awesome!

Keep in mind that WPA (at least versions 1 and 2; I'm not sure about 3) does not allow the client to reliably distinguish between inopportune packet loss and an incorrect password.  This means that, in my experience, the considerable majority of pop-ups asking for a password are actually erroneous.  Popping up a system-modal dialog in response is especially annoying in this case.

Honestly, given that GNOME seems to have settled on the absolute worst approach here, I think that it would be reasonable to change to using free-floating dialogs even without fully exploring the design space.  It will still be an improvement.  As Linus would say, "the perfect is the enemy of the good".  The current design is *bad*.

note.body:
I am having the same issue trying to sync my facebook event calendar to gnome-calendar.
This is using the latest build from the nightly flatpack repo (3.35.2-4df44cf9).
I would be delighted if this were to work as events I confirm going to on facebook would show up in gnome calendar.

Steps to reproduce:
- while logged into facebook go to https://www.facebook.com/events/
- copy the url linked to by the 'Upcoming events' link on the bottom right of the page. This is a hidden public URL of the form https://www.facebook.com/events/ical/upcoming/?uid=FOO&key=BAR
- Open GNOME Calendar
- Select "Manage your calendars"
- Choose "Add", "From Web"
- Enter calendar address
- The Add button on top right remains inactive, no feedback is provided.

This is using the latest build from the nightly flatpack repo (3.35.2-4df44cf9).
I would be delighted if this were to work as events I confirm going to on facebook would show up in gnome calendar.

Steps to reproduce:
- while logged into facebook go to https://www.facebook.com/events/
- copy the url linked to by the 'Upcoming events' link on the bottom right of the page. This is a hidden public URL of the form https://www.facebook.com/events/ical/upcoming/?uid=FOO&key=BAR
- Open GNOME Calendar
- Select "Manage your calendars"
- Choose "Add", "From Web"
- Enter calendar address
- The Add button on top right remains inactive, no feedback is provided.

debug output:
```
[...]
GcalCalendarManagementDialog-LOG-0x100: 15:29:26.490:   MSG: set_page():104: Switching to page 'new-calendar'
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:26.492: ENTRY: gcal_new_calendar_page_activate():501
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:26.494:  EXIT: gcal_new_calendar_page_activate():510
GcalCalendarManagementDialog-LOG-0x100: 15:29:26.494:  EXIT: on_page_switched_cb():184
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.083: ENTRY: on_url_entry_text_changed_cb():418
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.084:  EXIT: on_url_entry_text_changed_cb():449
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.585: ENTRY: validate_url_cb():339
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.585: ENTRY: discover_sources():207
GcalSourceDiscoverer-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.585: ENTRY: discover_file_in_thread():221
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.585:  EXIT: discover_sources():224
GcalSourceDiscoverer-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.585:   MSG: discover_file_in_thread():223: Creating request for https://www.facebook.com/events/ical/upcoming/?uid=FOO&key=BAR
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.585:  EXIT: validate_url_cb():353 
GcalSourceDiscoverer-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.757:   MSG: discover_file_in_thread():237: Message retrieved,  content type: text/html, status code: 200
GcalSourceDiscoverer-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.758:  EXIT: discover_file_in_thread():256 
GcalSourceDiscoverer-LOG-0x100: 15:29:31.758: ENTRY: discover_webdav_in_thread():274
GcalSourceDiscoverer-LOG-0x100: 15:29:32.441:  EXIT: discover_webdav_in_thread():308 
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:32.441: ENTRY: sources_discovered_cb():300

(gnome-calendar:2): GcalNewCalendarPage-WARNING **: 15:29:32.441: Error finding sources: Expected multistatus response, but 200 returned (OK)
GcalNewCalendarPage-LOG-0x100: 15:29:32.442:  EXIT: sources_discovered_cb():319 
[...]
```

I can not share the url for the calendar, but here are the headers for and part of the body of the HTTP response.
```
berz@host ~ $ http 'https://www.facebook.com/events/ical/upcoming/?uid=uFOO&key=BAR'
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Alt-Svc: h3-24=":443"; ma=3600
Cache-Control: private, no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Disposition: attachment;filename=uFOO.ics
Content-Encoding: gzip
Content-Type: text/calendar;charset=utf-8
Date: Sat, 18 Jan 2020 14:35:56 GMT
Expires: Sat, 01 Jan 2000 00:00:00 GMT
Pragma: no-cache
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=15552000; preload
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-FB-Debug: 0q1infsfk14cFlS1bZwIxp/ftaoBvuPD09WPgw7ZNSa241bEJgMjrMQY0EeKvZ0FbzPaoIaKlNYOUzekFyFZnA==
X-Frame-Options: DENY
X-XSS-Protection: 0

PRODID:-//Facebook//NONSGML Facebook Events V1.0//EN
X-WR-CALNAME:Facebook-events for berz
X-PUBLISHED-TTL:PT12H
X-ORIGINAL-URL:/events/
VERSION:2.0
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN
METHOD:PUBLISH
BEGIN:VEVENT
[...]
```

events.target_title: UX issue: Switching to next/previous picture on touchscreen is difficult
Touchscreen scrolling stuck in text/image selection mode after slow or stationary finger movement in KDE

note.body:
Touchscreen scrolling is unreliable also in Evince 3.34.1 on Ubuntu 19.10 and Lenovo IdeaPad D330 if the swipe crosses a text with OCR layer - selects the text instead of scroll.

When the wipe goes purely over the page margin/empty space, the scroll works fine.

events.target_title: OSK lacks Tab and Esc keys

note.body:
If Caribou allowed to select a keyboard layout and to design/tweak the layout by the user, it would become useful as a normal keyboard.

Or:

If Caribou was easy to replace with an alternative (Onboard, which has much better layout customization options), its layout could remain barebone as is - but currently Caribou is the only onscreen keyboard able to work in the list of applications and password prompts.

events.target_title: Onscreen Keyboard no full width on 2/3 screen

note.body: If design is needed, have a look at Hacker's keyboard for Android (opnesource, available via F-Droid repo). It uses a barebone layout optimized for SMS, similar to Caribou when the device has smaller screen size and is in portrait mode - and switches to wery well-thought full keyboard layout in landscape. On 10" tablet the full keyboard layout works great even in the portrait mode. So keeping rectangular keys is fine, just leverage the additional space in the landscape mode.

events.target_title: OSK needs (at least the option of) modifiers (Ctrl/Alt/Super)

note.body: I also have a convertible, 10" Lenovo Ideapad D330 with detachable keyboard. When detached, the device could be a very nice Linux tablet if Gnome support for keyboard-less devices was better. Many core Gnome apps lack touch-friendly controls and the on-screen keyboard lacks keys that could work around these "low-priority issues" that sit in the bug tracker for years unfixed. If at least could Caribou be fully replaced with Onboard, then most of the requests for richer layouts would be gone. But until Onboard can replace Caribou in the search field on the application list + in the password prompt, Caribou will remain the only on-screen keyboard for Gnome.

events.target_title: On-screen keyboard does not appear in many apps

note.body:
Firefox and Chrome are not Gnome-native apps and need special setup in order to leverage the touchscreen. I don't use Chrome but Firefox needs an evironment variable MOZ_USE_XINPUT2=1 and beware, Firefox doesn't source the .profile so the env variable has to be set system-wide, for example in /etc/environment.d.

Currently (Gnome 3.34.1 in Ubuntu 19.10) there is a reverse issue - Caribou appears even if the physical keyboard is present.

events.target_title: Disable on-screen keyboard when physical keyboard is available

note.body: The method for detecting a physical keyboard is already designed in Onboard and works quite well. (if Caribou was fully replacable also for password prompt and search in application list, Onboard could fully replace it without the need for reviving 5-10 years nearly dead project like Caribou - last release is 3 years old, most commits are 7-10 years old).

events.target_title: French BÉPO layout

note.body: 4 years ago Caribou received a new keyboard layout, see https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=760470 for the discussion and especially the attached patch. I guess it could reduce a lot of reverse engineering. Alas, I was not able to find out how to switch the keyboard layout (I would like to use the fullscale layout with en-US keyboard - maybe to add the -f /usr/share/caribou/layouts/fullscale/de.xml to the .desktop file for Caribou service? I struggle with understanding how the Vala daemon integrates with the Gnome shell).

events.target_title: Functional improvements [fullsize, multitouch, resizing]

note.body: It's unmaintained to the extent of not having a release in last 3 years. However, the https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=760470 and dpkg -L libcaribou-common which contains /usr/share/caribou/layouts/fullscale/en.xml give some hope for fixing of at least some of the missing features.

events.target_title: Touching my laptop's touch-screen moves my windows

note.body: Maybe the registered event handler in Caribou's daemon/daemon.vala, in particular Daemon.on_focus() is too greedy when grabbing all "object:state-changed:focused" events? I am not a Vala programmer and do not know much about Gnome's events but maybe it helps someone who knows more.

events.target_title: Cant save or export file Windwos 10

note.body:
Hello!
I have the same problem with opening jpg and png files. Also, I can't export the document to jpg or png format.

Operating system: Windows 10 64 bit
OS version: 1903

GIMP version: 2.10.14

Reproduce the error open the file: 
File > Open image > Select file type (only GIMP files are available .pat, .xcf, gih)

Error message: "could not open 'C:\Users\Имя user\Desktop\image.png': Unknown file type»

Reproducing a file export error in jpg or png format:
File > Export > Select file type (there are no extensions available for selection in the window)

Error message: "there is no known extension In this file name. Specify an extension in the file name, or select a format from the list.»

What did you try to do:
1. GIMP GIMP 2.10.14 reinstalled the current version and completely deleted the GIMP 2 folder in the Program files folder Before reinstalling it

2. My program interface language is English

Nothing helped.

Important!
Initially, after updating the previous version 2.10.10 to 2.10.14, all file formats were opened and exported without problems.
This may be a coincidence, but I found this error a few days after the next Windows update.

The following Windows updates were downloaded and installed automatically:
- Cumulative update for the Windows 10 Version for systems based on x64 processors, 2020 01 (KB4528760)
Installed: 15.01.20
- 2020-01 Cumulative update of the .NET Framework 3.5 and 4.8 for Windows 10 Version 1903 for 64-bit systems (KB4532938)
Installed: 15.01.20
- Malware removal tool for the x64 platform: January 2020 (KB890830)

events.target_title: Cant save or export file Windwos 10

note.body:
Hello!
I have the same problem with opening jpg and png files. Also, I can't export the document to jpg or png format.

Operating system: Windows 10 64 bit
OS version: 1903

GIMP version: 2.10.14

Reproduce the error open the file: 
File > Open image > Select file type (only GIMP files are available .pat, .xcf, gih)

Error message: "could not open 'C:\Users\Имя user\Desktop\image.png': Unknown file type»

Reproducing a file export error in jpg or png format:
File > Export > Select file type (there are no extensions available for selection in the window)

Error message: "there is no known extension In this file name. Specify an extension in the file name, or select a format from the list.»

What did you try to do:
1. GIMP GIMP 2.10.14 reinstalled the current version and completely deleted the GIMP 2 folder in the Program files folder Before reinstalling it

2. My program interface language is English

Nothing helped.

Important!
Initially, after updating the previous version 2.10.10 to 2.10.14, all file formats were opened and exported without problems.
This may be a coincidence, but I found this error a few days after the next Windows update.

The following Windows updates were downloaded and installed automatically:
- Cumulative update for the Windows 10 Version for systems based on x64 processors, 2020 01 (KB4528760)
Installed: 15.01.20
- 2020-01 Cumulative update of the .NET Framework 3.5 and 4.8 for Windows 10 Version 1903 for 64-bit systems (KB4532938)
Installed: 15.01.20
- Malware removal tool for the x64 platform: January 2020 (KB890830)

I was able to revert the change to dynamic disk (it was done when attempting to do the resize operation online on the windows server)

The Resize operation through gparted now worked - Thanks for a cool tool & the live disk to make it easy to work with.

Maybe it was an idea to disable unsupported operations on dynamic ntfs disks ?

Br,

Henrik

Rar file extracts to multiple GB+ (like a zip bomb) but 'unrar' decompresses the correct 16.8MiB

note.body:
Confirming the issue with file-roller 3.32.3 on Arch Linux.

With any rar archive it tries to extract the first file infinitely taking up the whole disk space unless unrar in installed on the system - then it works as intended.

note.body:
Yes. Five out of ten times I accidentally move around a dock instead of selecting it. 
I am sure it is a common issue to happen to anyone with a graphics tablet at least.
This would improve overall usability.

note.body: Indeed! Great idea! Also an ability to assign keyboard shortcuts for this, dynamics in general and to specific brush dynamics would be wonderful! This would save so many extra clicks while painting.

events.target_title: Bluetooth and Wi-Fi items in Power Saving are still ambiguous

note.body:
It is mainly not about the wording, and not about the menu usage at all, it is about the function in the background. And it is not about too much possibilities, the use case here is very common in "nomade" users and users work as contracted non-employee:

I am on battery and ssh-ing somewhere or open VPN connection.
When the power save activated, it turns off the wifi by default. 
The broken wifi connection successfully kills ALL of the ssh and VPN connections. The hanging up kills ALL of the processes running on remote end - e.g. tar-ing some very big directory turning my previous work to rubbish. So I WANT to disable the switcing off the wifi (and mightbe same for bluetooth)
The wording in Power management applet say "... can be ... off" - so one assumes when the button here is OFF, the power manager CAN'T switch off the wifi / bluetooth. 
Something like this should be done in the background:
```
wifi.powersave
NM_SETTING_WIRELESS_POWERSAVE_DISABLE (2): disable powersave
```

Instead the switch just switch off the wifi / bluetooth. The function for OFF here is meaningless as the intended switch off can be done in the GNOME somewhere else with much less effort, actually much easier.

And no, it is not about the too long list and function needs to be removed. It is just about implementing the function accordingly and undersating the background. 
If you think the function should not be here by any reason I do not know about, pls move the same switch to gnome-tweak-tools to prevent the necessary conf editing in the background.

In the use case described above, the "strong" and "middle" power savings are meaningless, I WANT to keep the wifi ON until there is any power.


Edited:
Actually the power saving sugegstions might be good idea in separate pop-up or pane or anywhere else, however removing the existing items instead of properly programming the functions just turning the system less usable.

events.target_title: Add context menu action for bookmarking partitions
Add context menu action for bookmarking partitions

note.body:
I have just recently moved from Windows to Linux (I don't use Windows in dual boot), so the drives are NTFS, the nautilus version that I'm using is **3.28.4**. 

While viewed from `+ Other Locations` it's not possible either to right click on the drives or to drag & drop them just like normal folders.

It seems that they are treated as different entities since opening them doesn't require double-clicking as defined in the preferences (they get opened instantly using only one click).

I also tried adding them to the left pane from Desktop shortcuts (which I've created earlier) but nothing happens after they're inserted/dropped as 
> 🔖 New bookmark 

So given that drag & drop doesn't work, it doesn't seem very obvious.

events.target_title: Add context menu action for bookmarking partitions

note.body:
Thanks!
I finally ended up adding the bookmarks using the `Ctrl + D` shortcut, since I could not add it using the GUI.

I think the suggestions could definitely make things more obvious.

Tiff files generated by GIMP cannot be deleted or used by other programs.

note.body:
I found an easy way to delete the file : open the .tiff file again in gimp (choose 'open as image') and then export again (overwrite the original file). After that delete works as normal. 
I didn't try it but I imagine it will work also if you choose a random file that has only one layer and then overwrite the file that doesn't delete with it.

events.target_title: Plug-in crashed: "file-png.exe" (C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gimp\2.0\plug-ins\file-png\file-png.exe)

note.body:
Same problem for me too. This is a real thing, in addition to other weirdness described below.

This is on a clean install of GIMP 2.10.14 on a new Windows 10 laptop. I used 2.8.x on my old laptop.

There are zero resource issues on this machine. I have memory and filesystem space to burn. "Resource Consumption" in Edit -> Preferences is set to very high values.

I'm getting "Plug-in crashed" error trying export to a variety of file types including tiff, png. Also: "Procedure 'file-tiff-save' returned no return values".

On rare occasions the export works; mostly it fails. On at least one occasion the export succeeded after a reboot, but then subsequently failed.

Perhaps this is related to the following very strange behavior, which is itself disturbing. Often on this installation I have difficulty starting GIMP using a variety of methods. Sometimes I will double-click the GIMP icon on my Windows desktop and nothing happens. Other times I will try to start GIMP by double clicking on a .xcf file in Windows Explorer. Sometimes I will try to open the .xcf file explicitly by right-clicking the .xcf file in Windows Explorer and then clicking "Open". Usually, but not always, GIMP fails to start.

Interestingly, if I keep trying, doing EXACTLY THE SAME THING multiple times, I can eventually get GIMP to start. For example, I might try to "Open" the .xcf file in Windows Explorer. Nothing happens. Wait 10-15 seconds, try again. Nothing happens. Wait some more, try again. Nothing happens. Try yet again. This time it starts. Very odd. There seems to be some intermittent failures (or, actually, successes) going on with launching GIMP, and perhaps also with the export plug-ins? Windows process-creation issues?? When trying to start GIMP I sometimes keep an eye on the processes in the Windows Task Manager to see if there's any sign of a GIMP processes trying to get going. There isn't.

The problem launching GIMP is not tied to any specific .xcf file. I've tried many. And as I said, attempting to launch by just double-clicking the GIMP icon on the desktop also fails.

events.target_title: Plug-in crashed: "file-png.exe" (C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gimp\2.0\plug-ins\file-png\file-png.exe)

note.body:
Took a quick look at the Windows Event Viewer -- not something I typically do. I see nothing noteworthy. But there's a lot of stuff in there, and I don't really know my way around it. Looked at "Administrative Events" and "Windows Logs" but no entries got my attention. I also took a look at the Event Viewer right after the crash of an export plug-in and didn't see any significant entries around that time.

Speaking of the export plug-ins, they continue to sometimes crash and sometimes work, without any discernible pattern. For example, I just now had an .xcf open and tried four times in succession to export it to a tiff. In this test it actually worked the first three times and failed on the fourth. I used a unique filename for each export attempt: bbb.tif (ok), ccc.tif (ok), ddd.tif (ok), eee.tif (crashed).

note.body:
One more thing. I would potentially be willing to assist in troubleshooting this matter with the direct guidance and supervision of some responsible party with the appropriate technical ability.

Absent that, I'll not mess with this much more. I've downloaded a couple of "portable" installations of older GIMP versions and will use them until this is resolved. events.target_title: add gretl.lang (or hansl.lang) to language-specs
add gretl.lang (or hansl.lang) to language-specs

note.body:
Hi, I'm from the gretl team (gretl.sf.net). Gretl has used gtksourceview for its built-in editor for a long time. We now think it would be good to distribute the gretl.lang file also upstream through you. Some questions about this:
First, how to proceed? Simply by attaching the file here?
Second, we're not sure about the naming. Gretl is a program, but it has a comprehensive scripting language which got the name "hansl" some years ago. Is it OK if the name id inside the lang file says "hansl", or should the file name then also be hansl.lang?  
Another more detailed question: To make the existing gretl.lang file work with gedit we had to comment out some sections referencing the external languages Stata and Ox. (Those languages enter the picture because we offer to have "foreign" language blocks embedded in a hansl script.) So far so good. But we could also contribute a stata.lang file. Would you like that or would you rather not have such closed-source software referenced?

If the new .lang file gets adopted, would it only be for version 4 or are there some updates still happening in version 3?

I've also read some things about a license statement that has to be included, is that right? 

Thank you,
Sven

events.target_title: add gretl.lang (or hansl.lang) to language-specs

note.body:
OK, so relevant instructions seem to be "GitLab workflow for code contribution - Using a fork - Non GNOME developer". Can you confirm this?
Any chance that some of my questions above can be answered before going to the merge request stage? 
thanks!

events.target_title: add gretl.lang (or hansl.lang) to language-specs

note.body: Hm, there is some truth to your last point, maybe we should just automatically install those files into that path (or actually several ones, for all gtksourceview versions). That way we'd have version 3 covered as well. Let me discuss this option with the gretl people.

events.target_title: gnome-documents using a lot of CPU

note.body:
I logged a ticket for this on Fedora's Bugzilla in December, but it hasn't been looked at.
[](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1786856)

My PC grinds to a crawl, and then I look and see that
 ![Screenshot_from_2020-01-21_09-07-23](/uploads/28eaecfcee4c1a6d2851ae32167594db/Screenshot_from_2020-01-21_09-07-23.png)
gnome-documents is hogging more than one entire core! 

I have to kill it because it's just too intense.  My machine lags when this is running.  And of course, it just comes back again a few hours later.

I don't know why it can't just run once and get done with it.  Why is it running so often, and so HEAVY?  It doesn't even have the decency to have a NICE value allocated to it.

I am very close to uninstalling this because, to be honest, I don't even know what it does for me!!

events.target_title: Search support in conversion UI

note.body:
I would like to suggest a solution that could be added alongside the search support in case of the currency combos.

I believe this would improve usability of the long combo list for those who often use the Calculator for quick rate conversion between a number of currencies. I'm not sure if the same approach would work well for the units conversion.

**Proposed solution:**

Add feature to allow the user promote a list of favourite currencies to the top of the combo list, the "favourite currencies" would be defined through the Preferences dialogue.

These currencies would be then promoted to the top, in alphabetical order, with the remaining list of currencies listed below with the two parts of the list separated by a horizontal line, for example if we assume that "Euro" and "US Dollar" are marked as favourite, the combo would look like this:

```
Euro
US Dollar
---------
Algerian Dollar
Australian Dollar
...
```

This way we could access the most relevant / most common used items quickly, without having to scroll through the long list every time we need to select the currency pair.

note.body:
I would like to suggest a solution that could be added alongside the search support in case of the currency combos.

I believe this would improve usability of the long combo list for those who often use the Calculator for quick rate conversion between a number of currencies. I'm not sure if the same approach would work well for the units conversion.

**Proposed solution:**

Add feature to allow the user promote a list of favourite currencies to the top of the combo list, the "favourite currencies" would be defined through the Preferences dialogue.

These currencies would be then promoted to the top, in alphabetical order, with the remaining list of currencies listed below with the two parts of the list separated by a horizontal line, for example if we assume that "Euro" and "US Dollar" are marked as favourite, the combo would look like this:

```
Euro
US Dollar
---------
Algerian Dollar
Australian Dollar
...
```

This way we could access the most relevant / most common used items quickly, without having to scroll through the long list every time we need to select the currency pair.

events.target_title: Add support for IOS4217 currency codes in Financial Mode
Add support for IOS4217 currency codes in Financial Mode

note.body: This sounds like the best approach - both user friendly and intuitive (I agree that having two separate preferences one for type of information second for sorting order would be confusing).

events.target_title: gtk3 FileChooserDialog regression: typeahead searches the local filesystem rather than selecting the item matching the typed text

note.body:
Hello, I'm adding my voice here as well, _showing up_ so to speak.

I do not wish to use Gnome nor GTK3's FileChooserDialog, yet I'm forced to nonetheless, as many applications are built using the GTK3 framework. I'm of the opinion that this fact places certain obligations on you - this (at this point old) change affects not only Gnome Desktop, but also users of any other desktop environment, if they need to use an application built with GTK.

By enforcing this design decision in the FileChooserDialog and not just Nautilus, you are responsible for creating a huge inconsistency in the user interface. In the five years since you've made this change, as far as I can tell, nobody else adopted a similar change: Windows, KDE, Qt and Mac all just search the current directory.

It doesn't matter whether this search is good or bad when considered alone. The fact that you do something else that the user expects from everywhere else means you're doing the wrong thing.

Now, again in my opinion, this decision is awful even when considering Gnome only. You're punishing users for knowing where their files are. It takes much longer for me to find the files with GTK3 FileChooserDialog. But all of this has already been said.

Again, I wouldn't care if this was a Gnome-only issue, but your stance is affecting everybody if they happen to be using something based on GTK3. That is why you're getting so many issues about this, as show in the original message in this issue.

I urge you to reconsider accepting a merge requests that would add an option to bring the old behavior back.

note.body:
Other editors that support column/block/rectangular selections:

* Geany
* Atom
* QtCreator

FWIW, Geany supports rectangular selection by virtue of using Scintilla instead of GtkSourceView.

* see also https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/issues/222
* see also https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/GtkSourceView/PainPoints

events.target_title: Add pollable GInputStream/GOutputStream around stdin/stdout/stderr

note.body: To add a usecase: I'm writing [nvim-rs](https://github.com/KillTheMule/nvim-rs), a library for writing [neovim](https://neovim.io/) rpc clients. I'm adding support for using glib/gio for the eventloop, and rpc plugins connect via stdio. As a comparison, GUI clients connect via stdio to a child process, which already works nicely via e.g. [g-subprocess-get-stdin-pipe](https://developer.gnome.org/gio/stable/GSubprocess.html#g-subprocess-get-stdin-pipe).

note.body: To add a usecase: I'm writing [nvim-rs](https://github.com/KillTheMule/nvim-rs), a library for writing [neovim](https://neovim.io/) rpc clients. I'm adding support for using glib/gio for the eventloop, and rpc plugins connect via stdio. As a comparison, GUI clients connect via stdio to a child process, which already works nicely via e.g. [g-subprocess-get-stdin-pipe](https://developer.gnome.org/gio/stable/GSubprocess.html#g-subprocess-get-stdin-pipe).

events.target_title: add prefix to duplicity to extend the command

note.body:
This is so good improvement, but in my opinion*, injecting raw prefix by env isn't the best solution. Rather as for me, let's Deja Dup having own settings specifically to limiting bandwidth based on `nice` or `trickle`  (or simply injecting prefix). Anyway, it could be a few settings/variants for both or more, and single place where prefix will be build from all possibilities. 

Limiting bandwidth is so useful feature and I dare say it could in future come as setting configurable by UI. 

\* To be clear, I'm not from this project's team or any GNOME-project.

note.body:
Prior to updating manjaro VM yesterday the default font which is set to "Cantarell Regular 10" (never changed) was displayed as a regular font in double commander and konsole.  The cantarell-fonts package prior to installion was version 1:0.111-1.   The update included cantarell-fonts package version 1:0.201-1.  After the installation text started looking bold.  No changes to default font setting were made and it is still set to "Cantarell Regular 10".

To illustrate better, I'm attaching screenshots. They are divided into 3 categories: before, during and after the installation.

Hopefully I've provided enough information. If you need more let me know.

Thanks!

Before installation:

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_pamac](/uploads/1f7f80967e38c60c0bdf914b216fef81/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_pamac.png)

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_fonts_settings](/uploads/0f0547909c5c229e82f366f91e1ce1db/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_fonts_settings.png)

As you can see file names and folder names appear completely normal.

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_double_commander](/uploads/7e9a59b493310cf2eb7d151f7249f2de/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_double_commander.png)

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_konsole_config](/uploads/10e2ba5516eb667dbd38e913f1f6ed39/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.111-1_konsole_config.png)

During installation:

And here are some anomalies I noticed while during the font package installation. These were cleared by restarting pamac.

![manjaro_vm_during_font_installation1](/uploads/ad564e53264a96f4608c08054bb11484/manjaro_vm_during_font_installation1.png)

![manjaro_vm_during_font_installation2](/uploads/5de7bc2bcb8a78875f0189fed53175a8/manjaro_vm_during_font_installation2.png)

![manjaro_vm_during_font_installation3](/uploads/f5de2a4515f1d6662f61def77e773a08/manjaro_vm_during_font_installation3.png)

After the installation:
After VM reboot file names and folder names in double commander as well as menu labels under konsole preferences display in bold.  This is while the font settings still show "Cantarell Regular 10". I doubt this was an intentional change.

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_font_settings](/uploads/a5dafb4f3b80b4f5fd6c9b204ee95262/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_font_settings.png)

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_pamac](/uploads/83fd883823bb7c579f37b24fc452423b/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_pamac.png)

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_double_commander](/uploads/75fd33fe2900edc2e7482c6856d0edf2/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_double_commander.png)

![manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_konsole_config](/uploads/c0b6e82db70e75bc891e78845e64f981/manjaro_vm_cantarell-fonts_1_0.201-1_konsole_config.png)

events.target_title: canterell-fonts v0.201

note.body:
Yes it's a Qt5 issue only GTK version of double commander is fine. Deleting Cantarell-VF.otf does fix the problem.  Also I did notice that the issue is with the Cantarell bold font, not the regular as I said initially.  Double commander uses cantarell bold 10 as a main font by default. It looks like the bold font got a lot bolder with v0.201 update.  For my situation I could just change the font to regular in double commander or as you mentioned delete Cantarell-VF.otf file. I don't like either of these options since: 

 * a) I have to apply either fix to over a dozen VMs 
 * b) If I delete Cantarell-VF.otf file a new update will simply put it back and I'll have to delete it again... 
 * c) If I fix it in double commander it may not be fixed in other applications.  

So it would be very useful to know if this change was intentional or not? If not will this issue be fixed in the next update?
Thank you!

events.target_title: pdf files are rendered but not printed

note.body:
I have a very similar situation, I use Ubuntu 19.10 with Evince 3.34.1 and a new Epson ET-2720 printer.
The Epson prints: Test pages, office documents and PDFs printed with LibreOffice Draw. If I send PDFs to the printer with Evince, Ubuntu will state the print job has been sent to the printer, the Epson printer indicates it receives the document, tries to processes it, then stops abruptly, finally Ubuntu states the print job has completed.
I also have an older HP OfficeJet Pro 8710. If I use Evince to sent the same test PDFs to this printer it is capable of processing and printing the information Evince generated.
These events are a strong indication that Evince unsuccessfully implements some printing standards.

events.target_title: Wrong time(zone?) in calendar events

note.body:
```
$ gnome-calendar --version
gnome-calendar: Version 3.34.2
$ pacman -Q libical
libical 3.0.7-1
```

Calendar with this issue: https://filmkreis.de/kalender

This calendar uses the `X-WR-TIMEZONE` property.

My timezone is Europe/Berlin (CET). The events on Tuesdays and Thursdays start at 20:00 hours but are displayed at 21:00 hours.

If I change the timezone to EET the event is displayed at 22:00 hours. If I change the timezone to GMT the event is displayed at 20:00 hours.

To me this appears to be an off-by-one error. The event should always be displayed one hour earlier than it actually is.

Wacom Bamboo Pen & Touch doesn't get detected as an input device.

note.body:
Resolved for me the same problem with complete deinstallation of:
Wacom-driver Version 6.3.38-2.
Tablet WACOM Intuos pro PTH-660. 
Gimp 64bit 2.10.14
Next step:
new installation of WACOM driver Version 6.3.38-2.
new installation of Gimp 64bit 2.10.14

Now Gimp and Krita have access to the pressure sensitive WACOM Pen in the input devices. please enable them if necessary.

The original source of this issue is the continous update of Windows 10 and all drivers. it looks like overwritten files inside the system. may also be, that the used Tablet API for Windows 10 is now deprecated. for example the Corel Painter Essentials 4 was working without my modifications. WACOM has currently 2 pressure sensitivity levels. one (the old compatibility mode) is restricted to 1024 digits. the second is the new introduced pressure sensitivity with more digits (range is unknown for me).

events.target_title: Gimp crash on Edit-> Preferences

note.body:
Never had an issue with this in 2.10.8 then when I installed 2.10.14 today it started happening to me, but even more when I uninstall 2.10.14 and reinstall 2.10.8 the latter doesn't even load, but crashes as soon as it tries to open.

Afterwords I only got 2.10.8 to work again by deleting all GIMP files I could find, .gimp-2.8, the GIMP folder in AppData/Roaming, and all GIMP, GeGL, Babl, gtk data in AppData/Local, so it starts right now, but it now also produces the same fatal error while proceeding to edit->preferences, while before it wouldn't!

Is anyone aware of more GIMP produced folders I can delete? Or maybe even tell me how to manually search for any registries to even delete those, like Gegl, Bable registries if they exist? 
I also find that GIMP has saved my project history, so there are some preferences still being preserved somewhere.

Much thanks in advance.

Update:
Also exporting images fails right now, this is quite an evil bug.

note.body:
@jayarmstrong Would you mind sharing your Actiona script here? I'm affected by the same issue and I'm having a hard time to find an easy solution.

In any case I'm actually quite surprised that this is still a quirk in GTK in 2020. I remember this was already a bummer back in 2005. Is it really that much work to make use the XFxxx-Keys in GTK? There are so many applications that would benefit from working cut, copy and paste special keys.
